objects.abstract:
Con il Decreto Assessoriale 103/GAB del 25/06/2021 è approvata la Carta delle aree vocate alla maricoltura e la Guida metodologica per l’individuazione delle aree vocate alla maricoltura – elaborata in conformità al metodo indicato alla fase 1 della guida tecnica di ISPRA. 
La cartografia costituisce un riferimento conoscitivo e non rappresenta l’assegnazione alle aree vocate di una priorità, o esclusività, d’uso per la maricoltura, che rimanda comunque al proponente di qualsivoglia impianto o concessione per diverse finalità le indagini sito-specifiche ed il monitoraggio ex-ante ed in-itinere, eseguito in funzione delle attività proposte, del carico ambientale, della sensibilità e della capacità portante del corpo idrico ricevente.

In questo guida sono state individuate le aree marine libere da vincoli e usi non compatibili e idonee all’attività di maricoltura, lungo la costa della Sicilia. A tal fine, sono stati definiti dei criteri utili per individuare le suddette aree, facendo riferimento alla pianificazione che vincola e regolamenta i diversi tratti di mare sulla base dei Corpi Idrici (CI) marino costieri individuati nel Piano di Gestione del Distretto Idrografico della Sicilia, ai sensi della Direttiva Quadro Acque 2000/60/CE.
In particolare, sono stati presi in considerazione le pressioni che insistono su ciascun CI e il giudizio di Stato Ecologico ad essi attribuito. 
Inoltre, sono stati utilizzate le informazioni e i dati esistenti sull'estensione e condizione degli habitat coralligeno, fondi a maerl e praterie di Posidonia oceanica acquisiti nell'ambito dei programmi di monitoraggio per l'attuazione della Direttiva Quadro sulla Marine Strategy (2008/56/CE). 
La procedura metodologica utilizzata è quella indicata nella guida tecnica per l’istituzione delle AZA (Allocated Zones for Aquaculture) redatta da ISPRA per la Direzione generale della pesca marittima e dell’acquacoltura del MiPAAF e pubblicata a dicembre 2020.
Nella guida sono indicati i parametri ambientali , oceanografici e logistici da prendere in considerazione, i criteri da utilizzare per contenere l'impatto contenere l’impatto sull’ambiente, su aree di elevata rilevanza naturalistica, sul paesaggio, per ridurre i conflitti sull’ambiente costiero, per tutelare gli ambienti sensibili, la popolazione. lo stato igienico-sanitario del prodotto e le altre attività a diretta fruizione del mare.
I limiti di rispetto e le distanze riportate nella Tabella 1 sono quelli indicate nella guida tecnica AZA, valutati sulla base della legislazione vigente, studi bibliografici e parere di esperti.

Dato scaricato da: https://www.sitr.regione.sicilia.it/geoportale/it/metadata/details/840

objects.name: Turismo_Costiero_Arrivi_2022
objects.supplemental_information:
The "Movement of Customers in Accommodation Establishments" survey is a total survey that is carried out on a monthly basis in accordance with Regulation (EU) No 692/2011 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 6 July 2011 governing European statistics on tourism and Commission Implementing Regulation No 1051/2011, as amended by Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) No 1681/2019. Monthly statistics on the movement of customers in accommodation establishments have been compiled regularly by Istat since 1957 and represent the main source of information on domestic tourism available in Italy. The survey quantifies, for each month and for each municipality, the arrivals and presences of customers (residents and non-residents) according to the category of establishment and type of establishment and according to the foreign country or Italian region of residence. The most interesting aspect of the data lies in the possibility of articulating the tourist movement of customers according to all possible combinations of the variables considered, so as to allow an in-depth analysis of the relationships between them. ISTAT also provides for the calculation of hotel capacity utilisation indices. 

These bed indices are made up of the ratios between the admissions recorded in the establishments and the availability of beds in the establishments and are divided into 'net' occupancy indices, if the availability refers to the days when the establishments are actually open, and 'gross' occupancy indices, if it refers to the potential of the days before seasonal closures. The net occupancy index of hotel rooms, on the other hand, is calculated as the ratio between the room-days occupied in the month and the number of room-days available in the month for hotels and similar establishments. The data on the daily movement of customers, communicated by the accommodation facility operators, are collected and summarised on a monthly basis, with municipal details (file according to the MOV/C record layout) by the Intermediate Bodies in charge of the survey, which forward them to Istat via the certified and protected site https://indata.istat.it/mtur.

objects.abstract: This Pilot Site is one of the seven selected as Case Studies in the BRIDGE-BS Project. This site covers shelf and slope of the region between Igneada and Sakarya Canyon including the İstanbul Strait. Main oceanographic feature is the inflow of the Mediterranean waters and injection of oxygen to the Black Sea anoxic layer. While this marine region will be the focus of science, activities in the City of Istanbul will host a number of impact generating actions such as the Living Lab an d High-Tech Summit and policy events. Food provisioning (biological corridor for fish migrations) and buffering against anoxia as an RMS represent key ecosystem services to be assessed and measured. Key multistressors include pollution from transportation. Inflow of invasive species, marine litter and underwater noise are other stressors caused by intensive maritime transport. Maritime transport and fisheries have been dominant sectors for the region for many years. The region also has an important potential for tourism, aquaculture and offshore energy (wind and wave) sectors.

objects.abstract:
Updated version of the macroalgae distribution map.  This map is compiled based on various field surveys that was carried out in recent years and data from the Bulgarian national monitoring programs. 

The new file consists of polygons that only have perennial brown macroalgae - which are the actual important macroalgal rocky reef habitats in our study site, they are hotspots of biodiversity, serve as nurseries grounds for fish, have high productivity and play an important role in the carbon cycles in the coastal zone. These polygons represent the spatial distribution of the following habitats, as classified in the MSFD national habitat types for the Bulgarian Black Sea:
Upper-infralittoral (1-4 m) rock dominated by Cystoseira bosphorica
Upper-infralittoral (3-10 m) rock dominated by Cystoseira barbata
Lower infralittoral (10-18 m) rock with dominant perennial sciaphylic red and brown macroalgae and/or widely adaptive green and  red macroalgae.

objects.abstract: This Pilot Site is one of the seven selected as Case Studies in the BRIDGE-BS Project. The site connects Western Shelf to the Western Basin, and focuses on fish migration routes with moderate outflow from rivers. The site is bound by coastal lakes-bays systems (Varna, Mandra). Upwelling (Kaliakra gyre) and rim current dynamics are the dominant features structing the habitats. The cities of Varna and Burgas are also part of the site. Key ecosystem services include food provisioning a nd habitat maintenance, with cultural services (heritage) also gaining importance. There are some preserved vulnerable habitats (mussel reefs, macroalgae and seagrass meadows) that are threatened by coastal pollution, invasive species (Rapana) and climate change. Other key multistressors include point, diffusive and atmospheric source of eutrophication/ pollution impacts and invasive species. The fisheries are the most important ones in EU Black Sea waters but most fish stocks are overfished. Aquaculture is emerging but limited to black mussel culture. Fisheries will be the main focus sector.
objects.name: bridge_bs_ps2
objects.title: BRIDGE-BS - Pilot Site 2 - Varna & Burgas

objects.abstract:
Shape file with the boundaries of the water bodies in the coastal zone of the Bulgarian Black Sea.

The important identifier is the BSWB_code column, which gives the official name of the water body designated by the WFD monitoring program of the EU. In the reports on the WFD data on the overall ecological status of each WB can be found, as well as specific ecological states evaluated for different elements of the marine environment, the so-called 'biological quality elements'. These include macroalgae, zoobenthos, and phytobenthos. There are also a number of physical and chemical parameters being evaluated. My suggestion is to try to combine the habitat types (infralittoral rocks, soft bottom types) with their respective WFD ecological status for each WB/municipality, then you will actually clearly see the change in the overall state of these ecosystems in the local gradients of pollution and eutrophication in the coastal zone. It will eventually give a good basis to get meaningful correlations between ESSs provided and the actual drivers of change in the 'quality' of these ESSs (antrhopogenic pressures of different kinds).

There's a lot of info on the WFD in the EC's portals, an overview is available here:

https://environment.ec.europa.eu/topics/water/surface-water_en
and here's a map of current evaluations by water bodies
https://www.eea.europa.eu/data-and-maps/explore-interactive-maps/water-framework-directive-2nd-rbmp

To get the actual status of the BQEs in each waterbody, we will have to look into the annual reports for Bulgaria, as what you see on the map above is an integrated evaluation, which takes the lowest value from all evaluated elements.

We have published a number of articles and reports that clearly demonstrates the links between ecological state of the different benthic communities and their functioning - for macroalgae, seagrasses and zoobenthic communities. We can provide you with references if you need to look into these in more details.

objects.abstract: This Pilot Site is one of the seven selected as Case Studies in the BRIDGE-BS Project. Western Black Sea (Danube Delta Region). The main characteristic is the Danube’s influence on the ecosystem components, functioning and services provided. The influence of the Danube River (the 2nd largest river in Europe, crossing 10 countries, 203 km 3 /year) is determinant for nutrients, organic matter, contaminants, litter and sediment transport to the sea. The Danube plume, resulting mainly f rom the runoff of the Chilia branch strongly influence the hydrochemical structure of the water column and biological productivity. City of Constanza will constitute the community side of this Pilot site. Key services including carbon sequestration (RMS) and water quality (RMS-CS). Euthropication, overfishing and overfishing are major stressors. Commercial fishing, tourism and offshore abiotic resource exploitation are dominant sectors in this region. Tourism (linked to water quality) is the focus sector.

objects.abstract: This Pilot Site is one of the seven selected as Case Studies in the BRIDGE-BS Project. City of Odessa is the focal point and also Dniester river in Moldova are also part of the Pilot site. The site is located on the north-western shelf of the Black Sea and includes the area of the Odessa Sea Port and the Gulf of Odessa. Ukrainian botanic reserve "Zernov's Phyllophora field” is an internationally important area (4025 km 2 ). It is located on the north-western shelf of the Black Sea o n the traverse of the Dniester estuary, and deeper parts of the Dniester bank. The ecosystem services of PS4 are greatly influenced by transformed river waters, that are formed by the stream flows of the Dniester, Dniepr and Southern Bug Rivers. The site is relatively shallow (max 50m) compared to other sites, rendering it more prone to benthic-pelagic-atmospheric coupling. Hence the maintenance of these benthic habitats represents a key service along with food provisioning. Pollution from maritime inputs along with deoxygenation are dominant multistressors. Biotech will be the focus sector.

objects.title: BRIDGE-BS - Pilot Site 4 - Odessa Bay

objects.abstract: This Pilot Site is one of the seven selected as Case Studies in the BRIDGE-BS Project. The easternmost site has high-relief coasts and narrow shelves, with high land-deep-basin connection. The oceanography is dominated with the Batumi Gyre and occasional mesoscale eddies driving productivity. The site is a potential overwintering ground for commercially important fish species, making food provisioning the most important ecosystem service here along with recreation and tosurism. Over fishing, invasive species and marine litter are major stressors. The city of Batumi (Georgia) will be the main focal point for the Living Labs of BRIDGE-BS. Harboringthe largest stock of the Black Sea, fisheries is the focus sector here.

objects.abstract: This Pilot Site is one of the seven selected as Case Studies in the BRIDGE-BS Project. The site contains the marine and landward side of the city of Sinop, and extends to the deeper edge of the continental shelf. The site also includes the delta of Kizilirmak River, the largest river of Turkey. The Black Sea Rim Current shapes the water column habitats along with the anticyclonic gyres in the region “Sinop eddy and Kizilirmak eddy”. Food provisioning (aquaculture, PS) and heritage/tourism (CS) are prominent ecosystem services. Important stressors are pollution from rivers and subsequent eutrophication and deoxygenation. Aquaculture will be the focus sector in the Southern Shelf site.

objects.abstract:
These files present the predictions of cetaceans densities in the Pelagos Sanctuary and in the Western Mediterranean, produced by Floriane Plard for the Pelagos Agreement (https://pelagos-sanctuary.org/pelagos-agreement/)
 
Grids include spatial cells of 10km per 10 km
Densities are the number of individuals per km²
 
In each file, there are 14 variables:
id = cell ID
EofOrigin = 
NofOrigin
onland = Whether some part of the cell are on land (0 = TRUE, 1 = FALSE)
Areakm2= Area of the cell in km²
Corrected_density_Winter_mean= mean estimated density in winter. This density is corrected for bias availability
Corrected_density_Winter_cv= coefficient of variation of estimated density in winter. This density is corrected for bias availability
Corrected_density_Summer_mean= mean estimated density in summer. This density is corrected for bias availability
Corrected_density_Summer_cv= coefficient of variation of estimated density in summer. This density is corrected for bias availability
Uncorrected_density_Winter_mean= mean estimated density in winter. This density is  NOT corrected for bias availability
Uncorrected_density_Winter_cv= coefficient of variation of estimated density in winter. This density is NOT corrected for bias availability
Uncorrected_density_Summer_mean= mean estimated density in summer. This density is NOT corrected for bias availability
Uncorrected_density_Summer_cv= coefficient of variation of estimated density in summer. This density is NOT corrected for bias availability
geom = geometry of the cell
 
Bias availability:  The most common reason why cetacean individuals are not available to be detected is them being submerged when diving. This availability bias is particularly important in species such as sperm whale, fin whale and Cuvier’s Beaked whale. Bias availability has not been estimated from the gathered survey data used in this analysis. Thus, previous estimates of bias availability have been collected from the literature (Virgili et al. 2019, Sigournay et al. 2020, Okamura et al. 2012, Laran et al. 2017) and similar surveys using robust protocol (see final report CALL 1) were used to correct animal densities. Because these values are highly uncertain but have a great impact on abundance predictions, models have been done both on animal densities corrected and uncorrected by bias availability. 
 
Extrapolations: Extrapolated densities are not given and replaced by NA. A gap analysis has been perfomed and informed about the extrapolated or interpolated values of each prediction point. The prediction points are the centroids of the cells forming the predicted maps. I analysed if each prediction point was included or not within the data-based environmental space. If a predicted point is included within this data-based environmental space, the associated prediction is considered as an interpolation while if the point is outside of the  data-based environmental space, it is considered as an extrapolation
 
Seasons: Winter: October to March
Summer: April to September

objects.abstract:
Bottom trawling and all trawling national ban within 3 nautical miles from coast and < 50 m of depth. 

Currently, the technical management measures adopted in Italy refer to Reg. (EC) 1967/2006. According to this regulation, technical measures related to the use of towed nets (trawl and quick) are
- Prohibition of fishing less than 3 miles from the coast or within the 50m isobath when
this depth is reached at a shorter distance from the coast. In any case, it is forbidden to use of towed nets within 1.5 miles from the coast is prohibited;
- Use of square-meshed netting with a minimum mesh size of 40mm in the codend or, from a 50mm rhomboid mesh (subject to prior notice).

More data available Here

objects.abstract:
Offshore wind farm potential locations for  implants provided by CoCoNet.

COCONET identifies groups of putatively interconnected MPAs in the Mediterranean and the Black Seas, shifting from local (single MPA) to regional (Networks of MPAs) and basin (network of networks) scales. The project is meant to enhance policies of effective environmental management, also to ascertain if the existing MPAs are sufficient for ecological networking and to suggest how to design further protection schemes based on effective exchanges between protected areas. The coastal focus is widened to off shore and deep sea habitats, comprising them in MPAs Networks. These activities will also individuate areas where Offshore Wind Farms might become established, avoiding too sensitive habitats but acting as stepping stones through MPAs.

The prediction points are the centroids of the cells forming the predicted maps. I analysed if each prediction point was included or not within the data-based environmental space. If a predicted point is included within this data-based environmental space, the associated prediction is considered as an interpolation while if the point is outside of the  data-based environmental space, it is considered as an extrapolation
 
Seasons: Winter: October to March
Summer: April to September
objects.name: PRED_Med_zcav0
objects.title: Cuvier's beaked whale (Ziphius cavirostris)- Predicted density-Pelagos agreement

objects.abstract:
These files present the predictions of cetaceans densities in the Pelagos Sanctuary and in the Western Mediterranean. 
Grids include spatial cells of 10km per 10 km
Densities are the number of individuals per km²
 
There is one file for each species:
Species=
bphy = fin whale
pmac = sperm whale
zcav = Cuvier's beaked whale
ttru = bottlenose dolphin
scoe = striped dolphin
ggri = Risso's dolphin
gmel = long-finned pilot whale
 
In each file, there are 14 variables:
id = cell ID
EofOrigin = 
NofOrigin
onland = Whether some part of the cell are on land (0 = TRUE, 1 = FALSE)
Areakm2= Area of the cell in km²
Corrected_density_Winter_mean= mean estimated density in winter. This density is corrected for bias availability
Corrected_density_Winter_cv= coefficient of variation of estimated density in winter. This density is corrected for bias availability
Corrected_density_Summer_mean= mean estimated density in summer. This density is corrected for bias availability
Corrected_density_Summer_cv= coefficient of variation of estimated density in summer. This density is corrected for bias availability
Uncorrected_density_Winter_mean= mean estimated density in winter. This density is  NOT corrected for bias availability
Uncorrected_density_Winter_cv= coefficient of variation of estimated density in winter. This density is NOT corrected for bias availability
Uncorrected_density_Summer_mean= mean estimated density in summer. This density is NOT corrected for bias availability
Uncorrected_density_Summer_cv= coefficient of variation of estimated density in summer. This density is NOT corrected for bias availability
geom = geometry of the cell
 
Bias availability:  The most common reason why cetacean individuals are not available to be detected is them being submerged when diving. This availability bias is particularly important in species such as sperm whale, fin whale and Cuvier’s Beaked whale. Bias availability has not been estimated from the gathered survey data used in this analysis. Thus, previous estimates of bias availability have been collected from the literature (Virgili et al. 2019, Sigournay et al. 2020, Okamura et al. 2012, Laran et al. 2017) and similar surveys using robust protocol (see final report CALL 1) were used to correct animal densities. Because these values are highly uncertain but have a great impact on abundance predictions, models have been done both on animal densities corrected and uncorrected by bias availability. 
 
Extrapolations: Extrapolated densities are not given and replaced by NA. A gap analysis has been perfomed and informed about the extrapolated or interpolated values of each prediction point. The prediction points are the centroids of the cells forming the predicted maps. I analysed if each prediction point was included or not within the data-based environmental space. If a predicted point is included within this data-based environmental space, the associated prediction is considered as an interpolation while if the point is outside of the  data-based environmental space, it is considered as an extrapolation
 
Seasons: Winter: October to March
Summer: April to September

objects.abstract: La cartografía incluida en este servicio contiene la delimitación de las Demarcaciones Marinas correspondiente a las Estrategias Marinas de España. Se entiende por demarcaciones marinas las subdivisiones de las regiones y subregiones marinas que constituyen el ámbito espacial sobre el cual se desarrollará cada estrategia marina, y son cinco: Demarcación marina noratlántica, Demarcación marina sudatlántica, Demarcación marina del Estrecho y Alborán, Demarcación marina levantino-balear y Demarcación marina canaria (Artículo 6.2 de la Ley 41/2010, de 29 de diciembre, de protección del medio marino). Las demarcaciones marinas se emplean como unidades marinas de ámbito nacional para la notificación a la Comisión Europea de acuerdo a la Directiva 2008/56/CE del Parlamento Europeo y del Consejo, por la que se establece un marco de acción comunitaria para la política del medio marino.
objects.constraints_other: La información se puede usar de modo libre y gratuito, siempre que se mencione al Ministerio de Agricultura y Pesca, Alimentación y Medio Ambiente (MAPAMA) como fuente. Además, cualquier usuario deberá incluir la siguiente nota: “Este mapa es de uso exclusivamente técnico y no debe considerarse como la delimitación oficial de las fronteras entre países vecinos”.
objects.data_quality_statement:
En el año 2010 la Dirección General para la Sostenibilidad de la Costa y del Mar, con el soporte técnico del Centro de Estudios de Puertos y Costas del CEDEX, realizó una representación cartográfica de las cinco demarcaciones marinas. Esta cartografía se utilizó para la aplicación del primer ciclo de las estrategias marinas de España, incluida la notificación a la Comisión Europea del artículo 4 de la Directiva Marco sobre la Estrategia Marina, en el año 2012. Esta primera versión ha sufrido varias modificaciones posteriores. Dichas modificaciones han surgido bien de mejoras técnicas de la información de base, o bien de directrices específicas procedentes del Ministerio de Asuntos Exteriores y Cooperación (MAEC). Las modificaciones son las siguientes: (i) se modifican los límites de las demarcaciones noratlántica y sudatlántica en la zona colindante a las aguas portuguesas, siguiendo las directrices del MAEC. Esta modificación se realiza siguiendo el principio de equidistancia, tanto en el Mar Territorial como en la Zona Económica Exclusiva. Dichas líneas de equidistancia han sido facilitadas por el Instituto Hidrográfico de la Marina (Ministerio de Defensa); (ii) se actualiza la delimitación de la demarcación marina levantino-balear para cumplir con la delimitación establecida en el  Real Decreto 236/2013, de 5 de abril, por el que se establece la Zona Económica Exclusiva de España en el Mediterráneo noroccidental; (iii) se extrae la delimitación cartográfica de las aguas marinas en el entorno de  Ceuta, Melilla e Islas Chafarinas, siguiendo directrices del MAEC, por no estar los límites oficialmente definidos; (iv) el límite con tierra de las demarcaciones marinas (inicialmente tomado de las masas de agua costeras del primer ciclo de planificación hidrológica) se modifica para hacerlo coincidir con la línea de costa oficial publicada en 2016 por el Instituto Hidrográfico de la Marina. A esta línea ha sido necesario realizarle una serie de ajustes cartográficos para conseguir una delimitación coherente que permita su introducción en la capa de polígonos de las demarcaciones marinas; (v) Se actualizan los límites entre las demarcaciones marinas y las masas de agua definidas como de transición en base a la capa de masas de aguas superficiales del segundo ciclo de planificación hidrológica 2015-2021. 
NOTA IMPORTANTE: La delimitación de esta capa responde a la necesidad de definir, desde un punto de vista técnico, el límite de las demarcaciones marinas como ámbitos de gestión. Por lo tanto, este mapa es de uso exclusivamente técnico y no debe considerarse como la delimitación oficial de las fronteras entre países vecinos.

EUSeaMap 2021: EMODnet seabed habitat map for GSA16 (EUNIS 2019) 

This layer is the GSA16 centered  portion of  EMODnet broad-scale seabed habitat map for Europe.

The EMODnet broad-scale seabed habitat map for Europe is a comprehensive, free and ready-to-use broad-scale map of physical habitats, harmonising mapping procedures and fostering a common understanding among seabed mappers in Europe. The map is also known as EUSeaMap.

objects.abstract:
Frpm Global Energy Monitor. European Gas Pipelines both in the state of Operating, Construction / In development, Pre-construction, Proposed / Announced / Discovered, Cancelled, Shelved, Retired.

The Europe Gas Tracker provides a comprehensive dataset of fossil gas infrastructure across Europe, within and outside of the EU, as well as a few other countries* within the European gas network such as Türkiye. The Tracker covers gas pipelines, LNG terminals, gas-fired power plants, and gas extraction sites. The map and underlying data are updated regularly, and each project has a dedicated wiki page on GEM.wiki that provides extensive detail on the project, such as the project’s status, capacity, cost and ownership.

objects.abstract:
These files present the predictions of cetaceans densities in the Pelagos Sanctuary and in the Western Mediterranean, produced by Floriane Plard for the Pelagos Agreement (https://pelagos-sanctuary.org/pelagos-agreement/)
 
Grids include spatial cells of 10km per 10 km
Densities are the number of individuals per km²
 
In each file, there are 14 variables:
id = cell ID
EofOrigin = 
NofOrigin
onland = Whether some part of the cell are on land (0 = TRUE, 1 = FALSE)
Areakm2= Area of the cell in km²
Corrected_density_Winter_mean= mean estimated density in winter. This density is corrected for bias availability
Corrected_density_Winter_cv= coefficient of variation of estimated density in winter. This density is corrected for bias availability
Corrected_density_Summer_mean= mean estimated density in summer. This density is corrected for bias availability
Corrected_density_Summer_cv= coefficient of variation of estimated density in summer. This density is corrected for bias availability
Uncorrected_density_Winter_mean= mean estimated density in winter. This density is  NOT corrected for bias availability
Uncorrected_density_Winter_cv= coefficient of variation of estimated density in winter. This density is NOT corrected for bias availability
Uncorrected_density_Summer_mean= mean estimated density in summer. This density is NOT corrected for bias availability
Uncorrected_density_Summer_cv= coefficient of variation of estimated density in summer. This density is NOT corrected for bias availability
geom = geometry of the cell
 
Bias availability:  The most common reason why cetacean individuals are not available to be detected is them being submerged when diving. This availability bias is particularly important in species such as sperm whale, fin whale and Cuvier’s Beaked whale. Bias availability has not been estimated from the gathered survey data used in this analysis. Thus, previous estimates of bias availability have been collected from the literature (Virgili et al. 2019, Sigournay et al. 2020, Okamura et al. 2012, Laran et al. 2017) and similar surveys using robust protocol (see final report CALL 1) were used to correct animal densities. Because these values are highly uncertain but have a great impact on abundance predictions, models have been done both on animal densities corrected and uncorrected by bias availability. 
 
Extrapolations: Extrapolated densities are not given and replaced by NA. A gap analysis has been perfomed and informed about the extrapolated or interpolated values of each prediction point. The prediction points are the centroids of the cells forming the predicted maps. I analysed if each prediction point was included or not within the data-based environmental space. If a predicted point is included within this data-based environmental space, the associated prediction is considered as an interpolation while if the point is outside of the  data-based environmental space, it is considered as an extrapolation
 
Seasons: Winter: October to March
Summer: April to September
objects.name: PRED_Med_bphy
objects.title: Fin Whale (Balaenoptera physalus) Predicted density-Pelagos agreement

objects.abstract:
Sum of Daily Fishing Effort at 10th Degree Resolution by MMSI, version 2.0, 2019

Fishing effort and vessel presence data is available in the following formats:
 - BigQuery Tables (global-fishing-watch.gfw_public_data.fishing_effort_byvessel_v2)
 - CSVs

Description:
Fishing effort and vessel presence is binned into grid cells 0.1 degrees on a side, and measured in units of hours. The time is calculated by assigning an amount of time to each AIS detection (which is the time to the previous AIS position), and then summing all positions in each grid cell. Data is based on fishing detections of >114,000 unique AIS devices on fishing vessels, of which ~70,000 are active each year. Fishing vessels are identified via a neural network classifier and vessel registry databases. Fishing effort for squid jiggers is not calculated through the neural network, but instead through this heuristic (https://github.com/GlobalFishingWatch/global-footprint-of-fisheries/blob/master/data_production/updated-algorithm-for-squid-jiggers.md).

Vessel information for each MMSI, including flag state, geartype, and vessel dimensions is provided in a separate file (fishing-vessels-v2.csv).

Table Schema:
 - date: Date in YYYY-MM-DD format
 - cell_ll_lat: the latitude of the lower left corner of the grid cell, in decimal degrees
 - cell_ll_lon: the longitude of the lower left corner of the grid cell, in decimal degrees
 - mmsi: Maritime Mobile Service Identity, the identifier for AIS
 - hours: hours that the vessel was present in this gridcell on this day
 - fishing_hours: hours that the vessel was fishing in this grid cell on this day

For additional information about the initial release of this dataset, see the associated journal article: D.A. Kroodsma, J. Mayorga, T. Hochberg, N.A. Miller, K. Boerder, F. Ferretti, A. Wilson, B. Bergman, T.D. White, B.A. Block, P. Woods, B. Sullivan, C. Costello, and B. Worm. "Tracking the global footprint of fisheries." Science 361.6378 (2018). (http://science.sciencemag.org/content/359/6378/904)

Unless otherwise stated, Global Fishing Watch data is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike 4.0 International license(https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/4.0/) and code under an Apache 2.0 license (http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0).

objects.title: Global Fishing Watch - Fishing Effort for the Black Sea (2019)

objects.abstract:
Sum of Daily Fishing Effort and Vessel Presence at 100th Degree Resolution by Flag State and Gear Type, version 2.0, 2012-2020

Fishing effort and vessel presence data is available in the following formats:
 - BigQuery Tables (global-fishing-watch.gfw_public_data.fishing_effort_v2)
 - CSVs

Description:
Fishing effort and vessel presence is binned into grid cells 0.01 degrees on a side, and measured in units of hours. The time is calculated by assigning an amount of time to each AIS detection (which is the time to the previous AIS position), and then summing all positions in each grid cell. Data is based on fishing detections of >114,000 unique AIS devices on fishing vessels, of which ~70,000 are active each year. Fishing vessels are identified via a neural network classifier and vessel registry databases. Fishing effort for squid jiggers is not calculated through the neural network, but instead through this heuristic (https://github.com/GlobalFishingWatch/global-footprint-of-fisheries/blob/master/data_production/updated-algorithm-for-squid-jiggers.md).

The current version of the GFW vessel classification neural net classifies fishing vessels into sixteen categories. Geartypes with nested categories are higher order classes that are assigned when the neural net and/or vessel registries are not confident enough in one of the lower level atomic classes. For example, the model may not score a vessel high enough to label it “pots_and_traps”, “set_longlines”, or “set_gillnets”, but collectively these classes score high enough to label the vessel as “fixed_gear”. The "fishing" class is assigned to vessels for which the neural net is unsure about the type of fishing vessel or when the neural net and registry information conflict.

Geartypes:
- fishing: a combination of vessels of unknown fishing gear
 - drifting_longlines: drifting longlines
 - seiners: vessels using seine nets, including potential purse seine vessels
   targeting tuna and other species, as well as danish and other seines
     - purse_seines: purse seines, both pelagic and demersal
        - tuna_purse_seines: large purse seines primarily fishing for tuna.
        - other_purse_seines: purse seiners fishing for mackerel, anchovies, etc, often smaller and operating nearer the coast than tuna purse seines.
    - other_seines: danish seines and other seiners not using purse seines.
 - trawlers: trawlers, all types
 - pole_and_line: vessel from which people fish with pole and line.
 - trollers: vessel that tows multiple fishing lines.
 - fixed_gear: a category that includes potential set longlines, set gillnets,  and pots and traps
     - pots_and_traps: vessel that deploys pots (small, portable traps) or traps to
       catch fish
     - set_longlines: vessel that fishes by setting longlines anchored to the
       seafloor. These lines have shorter hooked, typically baited, lines hanging
       from them
     - set_gillnets: vessel that fishes by setting gillnets anchored to the seafloor.
 - dredge_fishing: vessel that tows a dredge the scrapes up edible bottom
   dwellers such as scallops or oysters.
 - squid_jigger: squid jiggers, mostly large industrial pelagic operating vessels

Vessel information for each MMSI included in this dataset is provided in a separate file (fishing-vessels-v2.csv).

Table Schema
 - date: Date in YYYY-MM-DD format
 - cell_ll_lat: the latitude of the lower left corner of the grid cell, in decimal degrees
 - cell_ll_lon: the longitude of the lower left corner of the grid cell, in decimal degrees
 - flag: flag state, in iso3 format
 - geartype: geartype, see above description of gear types
 - hours: hours that vessels of this gear type and flag were present in this gridcell on this day
 - fishing_hours: hours that vessels of this geartype and flag were fishing in this grid cell on this day
 - mmsi_present: number of MMSI of this flag state and geartype that visited this grid cell on this day

For additional information about the initial release of this dataset, see the associated journal article: D.A. Kroodsma, J. Mayorga, T. Hochberg, N.A. Miller, K. Boerder, F. Ferretti, A. Wilson, B. Bergman, T.D. White, B.A. Block, P. Woods, B. Sullivan, C. Costello, and B. Worm. "Tracking the global footprint of fisheries." Science 361.6378 (2018). objects.title: Global Fishing Watch - Fishing effort for the Black Sea (2019) - 100th degree res

objects.abstract:
Sum of Daily Fishing Effort and Vessel Presence at 100th Degree Resolution by Flag State and Gear Type, version 2.0, 2012-2020

Fishing effort and vessel presence data is available in the following formats:
 - BigQuery Tables (global-fishing-watch.gfw_public_data.fishing_effort_v2)
 - CSVs

Description:
Fishing effort and vessel presence is binned into grid cells 0.01 degrees on a side, and measured in units of hours. The time is calculated by assigning an amount of time to each AIS detection (which is the time to the previous AIS position), and then summing all positions in each grid cell. Data is based on fishing detections of >114,000 unique AIS devices on fishing vessels, of which ~70,000 are active each year. Fishing vessels are identified via a neural network classifier and vessel registry databases. Fishing effort for squid jiggers is not calculated through the neural network, but instead through this heuristic (https://github.com/GlobalFishingWatch/global-footprint-of-fisheries/blob/master/data_production/updated-algorithm-for-squid-jiggers.md).

The current version of the GFW vessel classification neural net classifies fishing vessels into sixteen categories. Geartypes with nested categories are higher order classes that are assigned when the neural net and/or vessel registries are not confident enough in one of the lower level atomic classes. For example, the model may not score a vessel high enough to label it “pots_and_traps”, “set_longlines”, or “set_gillnets”, but collectively these classes score high enough to label the vessel as “fixed_gear”. The "fishing" class is assigned to vessels for which the neural net is unsure about the type of fishing vessel or when the neural net and registry information conflict.

Geartypes:
- fishing: a combination of vessels of unknown fishing gear
 - drifting_longlines: drifting longlines
 - seiners: vessels using seine nets, including potential purse seine vessels
   targeting tuna and other species, as well as danish and other seines
     - purse_seines: purse seines, both pelagic and demersal
        - tuna_purse_seines: large purse seines primarily fishing for tuna.
        - other_purse_seines: purse seiners fishing for mackerel, anchovies, etc, often smaller and operating nearer the coast than tuna purse seines.
    - other_seines: danish seines and other seiners not using purse seines.
 - trawlers: trawlers, all types
 - pole_and_line: vessel from which people fish with pole and line.
 - trollers: vessel that tows multiple fishing lines.
 - fixed_gear: a category that includes potential set longlines, set gillnets,  and pots and traps
     - pots_and_traps: vessel that deploys pots (small, portable traps) or traps to
       catch fish
     - set_longlines: vessel that fishes by setting longlines anchored to the
       seafloor. These lines have shorter hooked, typically baited, lines hanging
       from them
     - set_gillnets: vessel that fishes by setting gillnets anchored to the seafloor.
 - dredge_fishing: vessel that tows a dredge the scrapes up edible bottom
   dwellers such as scallops or oysters.
 - squid_jigger: squid jiggers, mostly large industrial pelagic operating vessels

Vessel information for each MMSI included in this dataset is provided in a separate file (fishing-vessels-v2.csv).

Table Schema
 - date: Date in YYYY-MM-DD format
 - cell_ll_lat: the latitude of the lower left corner of the grid cell, in decimal degrees
 - cell_ll_lon: the longitude of the lower left corner of the grid cell, in decimal degrees
 - flag: flag state, in iso3 format
 - geartype: geartype, see above description of gear types
 - hours: hours that vessels of this gear type and flag were present in this gridcell on this day
 - fishing_hours: hours that vessels of this geartype and flag were fishing in this grid cell on this day
 - mmsi_present: number of MMSI of this flag state and geartype that visited this grid cell on this day

For additional information about the initial release of this dataset, see the associated journal article: D.A. Kroodsma, J. Mayorga, T. Hochberg, N.A. Miller, K. Boerder, F. Ferretti, A. Wilson, B. Bergman, T.D. White, B.A. Block, P. Woods, B. Sullivan, C. Costello, and B. Worm. "Tracking the global footprint of fisheries." Science 361.6378 (2018). (http://science.sciencemag.org/content/359/6378/904)

 Unless otherwise stated, Global Fishing Watch data is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike 4.0 International license(https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/4.0/) and code under an Apache 2.0 license(http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0).

objects.title: HATCH Adswim monitoring data gee

objects.abstract:
Demonstration layer for using data with temporal characteristics.
The data was produced within the ADSWIM European Project (Interreg Italy – Croatia).
The layer was created within the Data Hub creation tasks for the HATCH project. HATCH is a one-year Interreg Italy-Croatia capitalization project concluded in June 2023.
The layer shows the sampling points and the relative presence of data as a function of time.
objects.name: shape_adswim_data_new
objects.purpose:
The aim is to make the points or areas affected by monitoring campaigns that have characteristics of time series visible and easily searchable.
Through this visualization it is possible to solve the problem of where and when monitoring campaigns have been carried out
objects.title: HATCH Adswim monitoring data temporal

objects.abstract:
Italian IBAs provided by the Italian National Geoportal (GN).  

The Important Bird Areas or IBAs are areas that play a key role in the protection of birds and biodiversity, the identification of which is part of a global project, managed by BirdLife International. The IBA project was born from the need to identify homogeneous and standardized criteria for the designation of SPAs. IBAs have been used to assess the adequacy of national networks of SPAs designated in Member States. To be recognized as an IBA, a site must possess at least one of the following characteristics: host a significant number of individuals of one or more globally threatened species; be part of a typology of areas important for the conservation of particular species (e.g. wetlands); be an area where a particularly high number of migrating birds is concentrated. The resource includes the 2002 inventory of land IBAs, updated in 2016 based on the studies on the Great Shearwater carried out between 2008 and 2014 which led to the identification of 4 new marine IBAs and subsequently in 2019, in order to resolve some discrepancies with the boundaries of the SPAs and with the natural and anthropic elements of the landscape.

objects.abstract: The IUCN Species Survival Commission Shark Specialist Group has developed an expert-driven innovative approach to ensure that discrete portions of habitats, critical to shark species – Important Shark and Ray Areas (ISRAs) – are delineated and used in various place-based conservation and management initiatives across global waters. Recent innovations and developments in animal tracking, data collection, and reporting have enabled the recognition of discrete areas of the ocean that are significant for various groups of endemic or highly mobile animals.

objects.abstract: Suitable areas for aquaculture in Liguria from Dapueto et al., 2015.
objects.name: a__4
objects.purpose:
https://www.researchgate.net/publication/280245416_A_spatial_multi-criteria_evaluation_for_site_selection_of_offshore_marine_fish_farm_in_the_Ligurian_Sea_Italy 

 

Mariculture is a relatively new activity that is expanding globally and interacts with other coastal uses.Therefore, it is necessary to allocate suitable sites from environmental, economic and social points ofview, involving different stakeholders in the decision-making process. In particular, in the Ligurian Sea(Italy), for its environmental characteristics and tradition, ﬁsh farming should be further boosted and anaccurate marine spatial planning should be done. This paper presents a spatial multi-criteria evaluation(SMCE) addressed to identify suitable areas for siting offshore medium size ﬁsh farms in the Ligurian Seaat the regional scale. The SMCE procedure follows an integrated approach that can be potentially adaptedand applied to any coastal system. The site selection is based on the deﬁnition of criteria that assess theirsuitability and on conditions related to the entire study area. Suitability values are ranked on a scale from1 (suitable) to 10 (optimal). More than 9000 ha were identiﬁed and almost 40% of this area gets highsuitability values, from 7 to 9, pointing out the untapped potential for Ligurian marine coastal zone.Results demonstrate that our SMCE, and in particular its procedure, allows identifying the most suitableareas in an easy and quick way and solving effectively the complex spatial problem of suitable site se-lection for ﬁsh farming.
objects.title: Liguria - Suitable Areas for fish farming

objects.abstract:
These files present the predictions of cetaceans densities in the Pelagos Sanctuary and in the Western Mediterranean, produced by Floriane Plard for the Pelagos Agreement (https://pelagos-sanctuary.org/pelagos-agreement/)
 
Grids include spatial cells of 10km per 10 km
Densities are the number of individuals per km²
 
In each file, there are 14 variables:
id = cell ID
EofOrigin = 
NofOrigin
onland = Whether some part of the cell are on land (0 = TRUE, 1 = FALSE)
Areakm2= Area of the cell in km²
Corrected_density_Winter_mean= mean estimated density in winter. This density is corrected for bias availability
Corrected_density_Winter_cv= coefficient of variation of estimated density in winter. This density is corrected for bias availability
Corrected_density_Summer_mean= mean estimated density in summer. This density is corrected for bias availability
Corrected_density_Summer_cv= coefficient of variation of estimated density in summer. This density is corrected for bias availability
Uncorrected_density_Winter_mean= mean estimated density in winter. This density is  NOT corrected for bias availability
Uncorrected_density_Winter_cv= coefficient of variation of estimated density in winter. This density is NOT corrected for bias availability
Uncorrected_density_Summer_mean= mean estimated density in summer. This density is NOT corrected for bias availability
Uncorrected_density_Summer_cv= coefficient of variation of estimated density in summer. This density is NOT corrected for bias availability
geom = geometry of the cell
 
Bias availability:  The most common reason why cetacean individuals are not available to be detected is them being submerged when diving. This availability bias is particularly important in species such as sperm whale, fin whale and Cuvier’s Beaked whale. Bias availability has not been estimated from the gathered survey data used in this analysis. Thus, previous estimates of bias availability have been collected from the literature (Virgili et al. 2019, Sigournay et al. 2020, Okamura et al. 2012, Laran et al. 2017) and similar surveys using robust protocol (see final report CALL 1) were used to correct animal densities. Because these values are highly uncertain but have a great impact on abundance predictions, models have been done both on animal densities corrected and uncorrected by bias availability. 
 
Extrapolations: Extrapolated densities are not given and replaced by NA. A gap analysis has been perfomed and informed about the extrapolated or interpolated values of each prediction point. The prediction points are the centroids of the cells forming the predicted maps. I analysed if each prediction point was included or not within the data-based environmental space. If a predicted point is included within this data-based environmental space, the associated prediction is considered as an interpolation while if the point is outside of the  data-based environmental space, it is considered as an extrapolation
 
Seasons: Winter: October to March
Summer: April to September

objects.abstract:
Marine Protected Areas. Source Ministry of the Environment and Protection of Land and Sea. DM 21-10-2009.

To date, only the area of the "Secche della Meloria" was established as a Marine Protected Area by Decree of the Ministry of the Environment and Protection of Land and Sea of 21 October 2009, which also approved the Regulations (by decree of 18 April 2014 and subsequent amendments of 18 July 2016). This marine protected area, the first in Tuscany, located in the sea off the Livorno and Pisa coasts, is characterised by the presence of marine habitats of extraordinary landscape and conservation value, consisting of alternating rocky areas with the characteristic basin-like seabed typical of the area and Posidonia meadows (a priority habitat under the Habitats Directive). 
The other areas include In particular, the areas on the islands of Giannutri, Gorgona, Capraia, Pianosa and Montecristo correspond to the protection areas at sea already provided for in the current planning of the Tuscan Archipelago National Park.

Data availability see HERE

objects.abstract:
Biomass of the deep scatering layer (DSL) in the Canary coasts. Biomass has been calculated from EcoPath-EcoSim models, based on a 2 km grid. The study area has been divided into five independent parts: Island of El Hierro, Island of La Palma, Islands of La Gomera and Tenerife, Island of Gran Canaria and Islands of Lanzarote and Fuerteventura. For each of the study areas, models of different species and/or groups have been made depending on the characteristics of each one.

This dataset compiles the species or groups of the five areas into a single trophic group for the whole archipelago. In order to compare the relative abundance between the different study areas, a normalized index has been calculated for each of them. This study has been carried out by the IU ECOAQUA-ULPGC and GMR within the context of the PLASMAR project. The data given are kilograms per square kilometer.
Methodological information at http://hdl.handle.net/10553/73660
PLASMAR/PLASMAR+ Project https://www.plasmar.eu/

The dataset is managed by the University of Las Palmas de Gran Canaria (ULPGC) and available at: http://www.geoportal.ulpgc.es/portada/index.html
objects.constraints_other: This service and its data may be used freely and free of charge, provided that the Instituto Universitario Ecoaqua - ULPGC is mentioned as the author, in accordance with the terms of the Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 License (Creative Commons Attribution)

objects.abstract: The dataset on Natura 2000 sites was created in 2014 by Cogea for the European Marine Observation and Data Network. It is entirely based on spatial data from the European Environmental Agency (EEA), plus additional info, links and selected EEA data joined to the feature attributes, as well as a calculation by Cogea of marine and coastal location of features. It is available for viewing and download on EMODnet - Human Activities web portal (https://emodnet.ec.europa.eu/en/human-activities). Natura 2000 is an ecological network composed of sites designated under the Birds Directive (Special Protection Areas, SPAs) and the Habitats Directive (Sites of Community Importance, SCIs, and Special Areas of Conservation, SACs). The dataset covers the whole EU. Following the United Kingdom’s withdrawal from the EU on 31 January 2020, it ceased to be part of the EEA’s institutional networks and governance. In the webmap the EEA dataset has been filtered by Cogea to show only (i) marine sites, i.e. sites with a marine area percentage higher than 0 (as calculated by the EEA) and (ii) sites that, even if not identified as marine by the EEA, intersect the EEA coastline or that are within a distance of 1 km from the coastline (using a 1 km inner buffer from the EEA coastline). In both cases the COAST_MAR field value=1. The EEA coastline dataset is available at https://www.eea.europa.eu/data-and-maps/data/eea-coastline-for-analysis-2. Compared with the previous version, this one includes the updated dataset 'Natura 2000 End 2021', published by the EEA in April 2021. For further information (e.g. biogeographic region, directive, habitats, sites, impact, management, species and metadata) please visit the EEA's website hosting the Natura 2000 tabular data.
objects.category__gn_description: Nature and species conservation sites & protected areas

EMODnet - Human Activities accepts no responsibility or liability whatsoever for the re-use of content accessible on its website. As regards Natura 2000, there are specific terms and conditions relating to the use of downloaded boundary data within the United Kingdom. If you intend to use the UK data you must first agree to the end user licence http://www.jncc.gov.uk/page-5232. This data is provided for general information purposes only. Only the data possessed by the competent authorities of the Member States is authentic. Therefore, no rights or legal claims can be derived from the data displayed on this site.

objects.abstract:
The layer represents the extent of the Particularly Sensitive Sea Area of the Northern-Western Mediterranean Sea, as designated by the Marine Environment Protection Committee of the IHO with the resolution MEPC.380(80) adopted on 7 July 2023.

The PSSA encompasses the existing Spanish "Mediterranean Cetacean Migration Corridor" and the Pelagos Sanctuary.

This map shall be used without prejudice to the agreements that will be concluded between Member States or between Member States and non-EU states in respect of their marine borders.".
objects.data_quality_statement:
The layer has been created starting from the dataset "MSFD regions and subregions - version 2, Oct. 2022" (available from the EEA geospatial data catalogue https://sdi.eea.europa.eu/catalogue/srv/eng/catalog.search#/metadata/a60e171d-e2a8-4dc5-a765-c2bdabbdbce6) and the geographical coordinates contained in the document "Designation of the North-Western Mediterranean Sea as a particularly seansitive sea area",  Annex 20 of the
resolution MEPC.380(80)
(adopted on 7 July 2023), and described also here: https://www.marineregulations.news/mepc-380-80-designation-of-the-north-western-mediterranean-sea-as-a-particularly-sensitive-sea-area/

objects.abstract:
OSMOSE (METU)
The spatio-temporal OSMOSE (Shin and Cury, 2001) model of the Black Sea includes 8 species:  European anchovy (Engraulis encrasicolus), European sprat (Sprattus sprattus), Atlantic horse mackerel (Trachurus mediterraneus), bonito (Sarda sarda), bluefish (Pomatomus saltator), turbot (Psetta maxima maeotica), whiting (Merlangius merlangus) and red mullet (Mullus barbatus). The model has horizontal (2D) spatial dimension and has a 4-km resolution. The migratory species, anchovy, bonito and bluefish, have prescribed migrations. Bonito and bluefish migrate to the Marmara Sea in early fall and then back to the Black Sea in late spring for spawning during the summer season. The 0+ age groups of bluefish and bonito do not migrate and stay in the BLack Sea the whole year round. Anchovy carries out migration to the northwestern shelf for spawning in summer and migrates back to the southern Black Sea for wintering. The Black Sea OSMOSE model is one-way and offline coupled to the LTL model of the Black Sea for the representation of resources; i.e. plankton and detritus, for the fish species. The model is set up for the initial conditions of 2000 and validated for the 2000-2020 period.

The 0+ age groups of bluefish and bonito do not migrate and stay in the BLack Sea the whole year round. Anchovy carries out migration to the northwestern shelf for spawning in summer and migrates back to the southern Black Sea for wintering. The Black Sea OSMOSE model is one-way and offline coupled to the LTL model of the Black Sea for the representation of resources; i.e. plankton and detritus, for the fish species. The model is set up for the initial conditions of 2000 and validated for the 2000-2020 period.
objects.name: OSMOSE_mean_fish_biomass
objects.title: OSMOSE Model - Mean Fish Biomass

objects.abstract:
OSMOSE (METU)
The spatio-temporal OSMOSE (Shin and Cury, 2001) model of the Black Sea includes 8 species:  European anchovy (Engraulis encrasicolus), European sprat (Sprattus sprattus), Atlantic horse mackerel (Trachurus mediterraneus), bonito (Sarda sarda), bluefish (Pomatomus saltator), turbot (Psetta maxima maeotica), whiting (Merlangius merlangus) and red mullet (Mullus barbatus). The model has horizontal (2D) spatial dimension and has a 4-km resolution. The migratory species, anchovy, bonito and bluefish, have prescribed migrations. Bonito and bluefish migrate to the Marmara Sea in early fall and then back to the Black Sea in late spring for spawning during the summer season. The 0+ age groups of bluefish and bonito do not migrate and stay in the BLack Sea the whole year round. Anchovy carries out migration to the northwestern shelf for spawning in summer and migrates back to the southern Black Sea for wintering. The Black Sea OSMOSE model is one-way and offline coupled to the LTL model of the Black Sea for the representation of resources; i.e. plankton and detritus, for the fish species. The model is set up for the initial conditions of 2000 and validated for the 2000-2020 period.
objects.name: OSMOSE_mean_fish_yield
objects.title: OSMOSE Model - Mean Fish Yield

The map constitutes a cognitive reference and does not represent the assignment of a priority, or exclusivity, of use for mariculture to the areas suitable for mariculture, which in any case refers the proponent of any plant or concession for different purposes to site-specific surveys and ex-ante and in-itinere monitoring, carried out according to the proposed activities, the environmental load, the sensitivity and the carrying capacity of the receiving water body. Council Decree 103/GAB of 25/06/2021 approved the map of areas suitable for mariculture and the methodological guide for identifying areas suitable for mariculture - drawn up in accordance with the method indicated in phase 1 of the ISPRA technical guide.
objects.name: Vocate_aquacultura
objects.purpose:
In this guide, the marine areas free from constraints and incompatible uses and suitable for mariculture activities, along the coast of Sicily, have been identified. To this end, useful criteria have been defined to identify the aforementioned areas, referring to the planning that constrains and regulates the different stretches of sea on the basis of the Marine Coastal Bodies (ICs) identified in the Management Plan of the Hydrographic District of Sicily, pursuant to the Water Framework Directive 2000/60/EC.
In particular, the pressures insisting on each IC and the Ecological Status rating attributed to them were taken into consideration. 
In addition, existing information and data on the extent and condition of coralligenous habitats, maerl beds and Posidonia oceanica meadows acquired as part of the monitoring programmes for the implementation of the Marine Strategy Framework Directive (2008/56/EC) were used. 
The methodological procedure used is that indicated in the technical guide for the establishment of AZAs (Allocated Zones for Aquaculture) drawn up by ISPRA for the MiPAAF Directorate General for Marine Fisheries and Aquaculture and published in December 2020.
objects.supplemental_information:
The guide indicates the environmental, oceanographic and logistic parameters to be taken into consideration, the criteria to be used to contain the impact on the environment, on areas of high naturalistic relevance, on the landscape, to reduce conflicts on the coastal environment, to protect sensitive environments, the population. the hygienic and sanitary status of the product and other activities directly benefiting the sea.

The respect limits and distances reported in Table 1 are those indicated in the AZA technical guide, assessed on the basis of current legislation, bibliographic studies and expert opinion. Council Decree 103/GAB of 25/06/2021 approved the map of areas suitable for mariculture and the methodological guide for identifying areas suitable for mariculture - drawn up in accordance with the method indicated in phase 1 of the ISPRA technical guide.

The map constitutes a cognitive reference and does not represent the assignment of a priority, or exclusivity, of use for mariculture to the areas suitable for mariculture, which in any case refers the proponent of any plant or concession for different purposes to site-specific surveys and ex-ante and in-itinere monitoring, carried out according to the proposed activities, the environmental load, the sensitivity and the carrying capacity of the receiving water body.

https://www.sitr.regione.sicilia.it/wp-content/uploads/aza_A3_2_decreto.pdf
objects.title: Potential Aquaculture Areas Sicily

objects.abstract: Total number of presences of customers (residential and non ) per each Coastal Municipality in Italy for 2022 acquired by the ISTAT Database
objects.name: Tursimo_Costiero_Presenze_2022
objects.supplemental_information:
The "Movement of Customers in Accommodation Establishments" survey is a total survey that is carried out on a monthly basis in accordance with Regulation (EU) No 692/2011 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 6 July 2011 governing European statistics on tourism and Commission Implementing Regulation No 1051/2011, as amended by Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) No 1681/2019. Monthly statistics on the movement of customers in accommodation establishments have been compiled regularly by Istat since 1957 and represent the main source of information on domestic tourism available in Italy. The survey quantifies, for each month and for each municipality, the arrivals and presences of customers (residents and non-residents) according to the category of establishment and type of establishment and according to the foreign country or Italian region of residence. The most interesting aspect of the data lies in the possibility of articulating the tourist movement of customers according to all possible combinations of the variables considered, so as to allow an in-depth analysis of the relationships between them. ISTAT also provides for the calculation of hotel capacity utilisation indices. 

These bed indices are made up of the ratios between the admissions recorded in the establishments and the availability of beds in the establishments and are divided into 'net' occupancy indices, if the availability refers to the days when the establishments are actually open, and 'gross' occupancy indices, if it refers to the potential of the days before seasonal closures. The net occupancy index of hotel rooms, on the other hand, is calculated as the ratio between the room-days occupied in the month and the number of room-days available in the month for hotels and similar establishments. The data on the daily movement of customers, communicated by the accommodation facility operators, are collected and summarised on a monthly basis, with municipal details (file according to the MOV/C record layout) by the Intermediate Bodies in charge of the survey, which forward them to Istat via the certified and protected site https://indata.istat.it/mtur.
objects.title: Presences Coastal Municipalities Italy 2022

objects.abstract:
Floating regasifier terminal FSRU "TOSCANA" - It is positioned at 43°38.67'N -
009°59.33'E, about 14.5 M from the port of Livorno, by means of an anchoring system that allows its
free rotation at 360°, it is connected to the coast by an underwater pipeline; it is signalled by 4
lanterns.
objects.name: Limited_Zone_Contours
objects.purpose:
In order to guarantee the safety of navigation, three circular areas have been planned with
centre of the terminal:


(a) Area 1 (Total Prohibition Zone) with a radius of 2 M; In this area, navigation, stopping, anchoring, fishing as well as any other activity is prohibited
surface or underwater.
Entry to this area is only permitted to:
 LNG carriers bound for the terminal (authorised by the Livorno Port Authority); Vessels necessary for mooring/unmooring operations of LNG carriers; Vessels operating on the terminal for the transport of personnel/merchandise and related activities; Guard ship; Police vehicles (they will have to inform the terminal in the vicinity of the area of total prohibition); Nautical means expressly authorised from time to time by the Port Authority of
Livorno.


b) Area 2 (Limitation Zone) with a radius of 4 M; In this area, any type of activity is prohibited except for transit at a speed not exceeding 10 knots.
 The routes of the transit units shall be straight and set in such a way as to exclude transit in the no-go zone (area 1).

(c) Area 3 (Warning Zone) with a radius of 8 M;Stopping in this area is only allowed for proven necessities and/or emergencies by notifying
immediately informing the Livorno Port Authority (operations room) of the reasons for such conduct.
determined such conduct. Should the weather conditions so advise or in any case at the unquestionable judgement of the Port Authority of Livorno, one or more tugs may be dispatched for assistance.
tugs. All units that are in this area will be subject to route monitoring and plotting also by the terminal (FSRU).
In the vicinity of the outer limits of Area 1, as an integrated aid to monitoring the above areas an LNG Guardian ship will be present, with vigilance as well as patrol duties, fire-fighting and anti-pollution first aid.

More info HERE
objects.title: Re-Gasifier Limited Zones - Livorno

objects.abstract: Important Bird Areas, or IBAs, are areas that play a key role in safeguarding birds and biodiversity, the identification of which is part of a worldwide project overseen by BirdLife International. From Regione Sicilia
objects.name: IBA1
objects.purpose: Important Bird Areas, or IBAs, are areas that play a key role in safeguarding birds and biodiversity, the identification of which is part of a worldwide project overseen by BirdLife International. The IBA project arose from the need to identify uniform and standardised criteria for the designation of SPAs. IBAs were used to assess the adequacy of the national networks of designated SPAs in the member states. In order to be recognised as an IBA, a site must possess at least one of the following characteristics: host a significant number of individuals of one or more globally threatened species; be part of a type of area important for the conservation of particular species (e.g. wetlands); be an area where a particularly high number of migrating birds are concentrated. Source:https://www.sitr.regione.sicilia.it/portal/home/item.html?id=4b1ce619a48b4b14855d9168f4124a94
objects.title: Sicily Important Bird Areas

objects.abstract:
Locations from 4COffshore https://map.4coffshore.com/offshorewind/ at stage of concept and early planning from different providers.

 

The Polygons represent several projects including from top left to bottom right:

Renexia - has completed the first phase of geotechnical surveys including penetration tests of up to 40 m below the seabed in the strait if Sicily, at depths of up to 900 m. Seas Geosciences carried out the site investigations using remotely operated systems, with the aim of finding the optimum anchoring sites for the FOWTs. Capacity:
2793 MW

Calypso: Documents for the SIA have been submitted and are under administrative verification. This is a project of a floating offshore wind power plant, called "Calypso", consisting of 40 wind turbines of 15 MW each, and the related works for connection to the NTG, for a total power of 600 MW, partly in the province of Trapani, in the Municipalities of Petrosino (TP) and Misiliscemi (TP) and Marsala (TP) , off the west coast of the Sicily Region.Capacity:600 MW 

Mazar Wind S.r.l. sent a request on 17 November 2022 to the authorities for a maritime concession off the coast of Sicily for a period of 40 years to construct and operate a 1100 MW floating offshore wind farm. capacity 1110MW

Elymo Floating: 29 Nov 2022: Elymo is currently preparing a preliminary environmental assessment to submit to the Ministry of Ecological Transition (MiTe) and relevant port authorities (Mazara del Vallo). Capacity: 585MW

Hannibal Floating: 25 Sep 2023: As of September 2023, the 250 MW project has completed scoping and is progressing with the Environmental Impact Assessment (EIA)/Valutazione Impatto Ambientale (VIA).Capacity: 250MW

Hymed Floating: 26 Sep 2022: In September 2022, Aquaterra Energy and Seawind Ocean Technology announced that they will develop a floating wind and green hydrogen production park, named HyMed, with 3.2GW of production expected by 2027 in ultra-deep waters. Capacity: 2200MW

MDV Floating Wind Farm:23 Jun 2022: Regolo Rinnovabili s.r.l. sent an application on 23 June 2022 requesting a maritime concession for a period of 30 years for the construction and operation of a floating offshore wind farm in the stretch of sea in front of Mazara del Vallo. The project will consist of 34 turbines (1 rated 9 MW, 33 rated 15 MW). Capacity 504MW

Mazara del Vallo 3 Floating Wind Farm: 22 Mar 2023: Submission of EIA documents to Ministry of Ecological Transition (MITE). 810MW

Elymo B Floating Wind Farm: 29 Nov 2022: Elymo is currently preparing a preliminary environmental assessment to submit to the Ministry of Ecological Transition (MiTe) and relevant port authorities (Mazara del Vallo). 435MW

Ostro Floating Wind Farm: 23 Dec 2022: “OCEAN WINDS OW S.r.l.” with an application sent on 23 December 2022 to the Directorate General for the Supervision of the Port System Authorities, Maritime Transport and Internal Waterways of the Ministry of Infrastructure and Transport, requested the release of a state-owned maritime concession for a period of 30 years for the construction and operation of a 600 MWs offshore wind farm called "OSTRO", located off the south-west coast of Sicily. 600MW

Mazara del Vallo 2 Floating Wind Farm: 12 Dec 2022: NINFEA RENEWABLES S.r.l. with an application sent on 12 December 2022 to the Directorate General for the Supervision of the Port System Authorities, Maritime Transport and Internal Waterways of the Ministry of Infrastructure and Transport, requested the release of a maritime state concession for a period of 30 years for the construction and operation of an offshore wind farm called "MAZARA DEL VALLO 2", located in the stretch of sea in front of Mazara del Vallo. 795MW

Sicilia 495 MW Floating Wind Farm: 21 Nov 2022: INERGIA S.p.a. with an application sent on 11/21/2022 to the Directorate General for the Supervision of the Port System Authorities, Maritime Transport and Internal Waterways of the Ministry of Infrastructure and Transport, requested the release of a maritime state concession for a period of 30 years for the construction and operation of an offshore wind farm called "SICILIA 495MW", located in the stretch of sea in front of Mazara del Vallo (TP). 495MW

Sicily South - AvenHexicon Floating Wind Farm: 01 Dec 2023: Environmental Impact Assessment (EIA) and technical works (planned for 2023) are the next key steps. 1200MW

Gulf of Gela Floating Wind Farm: 03 Dec 2021: Apollo Wind srl have submitted the SIA content definition for a 384 MW offshore wind farm located in the Gulf of Gela, within the southern sector of the marine zone C of the "Canale di Sicilia". The water depths in this range are approx. 200m so it is assumed that this project would be floating. The applications is currently in administrative verification. 384MW

Sicilia B Floating Wind Farm: 10 May 2022: ACCIONA requested the release of the maritime state concession, for a period of 30 years, of a body of water located off the southern coast of Sicily in the central part of the Strait of Sicily, for the installation and operation of an offshore wind farm consisting of 67 floating turbines. 1005MW

Scicli Floating Wind Farm: 02 Nov 2023: Maritime concession granted. 750MW

objects.abstract:
These files present the predictions of cetaceans densities in the Pelagos Sanctuary and in the Western Mediterranean, produced by Floriane Plard for the Pelagos Agreement (https://pelagos-sanctuary.org/pelagos-agreement/)
 
Grids include spatial cells of 10km per 10 km
Densities are the number of individuals per km²
 
In each file, there are 14 variables:
id = cell ID
EofOrigin = 
NofOrigin
onland = Whether some part of the cell are on land (0 = TRUE, 1 = FALSE)
Areakm2= Area of the cell in km²
Corrected_density_Winter_mean= mean estimated density in winter. This density is corrected for bias availability
Corrected_density_Winter_cv= coefficient of variation of estimated density in winter. This density is corrected for bias availability
Corrected_density_Summer_mean= mean estimated density in summer. This density is corrected for bias availability
Corrected_density_Summer_cv= coefficient of variation of estimated density in summer. This density is corrected for bias availability
Uncorrected_density_Winter_mean= mean estimated density in winter. This density is  NOT corrected for bias availability
Uncorrected_density_Winter_cv= coefficient of variation of estimated density in winter. This density is NOT corrected for bias availability
Uncorrected_density_Summer_mean= mean estimated density in summer. This density is NOT corrected for bias availability
Uncorrected_density_Summer_cv= coefficient of variation of estimated density in summer. This density is NOT corrected for bias availability
geom = geometry of the cell
 
Bias availability:  The most common reason why cetacean individuals are not available to be detected is them being submerged when diving. This availability bias is particularly important in species such as sperm whale, fin whale and Cuvier’s Beaked whale. Bias availability has not been estimated from the gathered survey data used in this analysis. Thus, previous estimates of bias availability have been collected from the literature (Virgili et al. 2019, Sigournay et al. 2020, Okamura et al. 2012, Laran et al. 2017) and similar surveys using robust protocol (see final report CALL 1) were used to correct animal densities. Because these values are highly uncertain but have a great impact on abundance predictions, models have been done both on animal densities corrected and uncorrected by bias availability. 
 
Extrapolations: Extrapolated densities are not given and replaced by NA. A gap analysis has been perfomed and informed about the extrapolated or interpolated values of each prediction point. The prediction points are the centroids of the cells forming the predicted maps. I analysed if each prediction point was included or not within the data-based environmental space. If a predicted point is included within this data-based environmental space, the associated prediction is considered as an interpolation while if the point is outside of the  data-based environmental space, it is considered as an extrapolation
 
Seasons: Winter: October to March
Summer: April to September

objects.abstract:
Public Data only showing the records reported to General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean (GFCM) for Vulnerable Marine Ecosystems (VME) indicator species encounter in from 1974 until 2023.

Public Data only from https://www.fao.org/gfcm/data/maps/sbhs/zh/. 

The database aims to store data and facilitate the analysis of all known VME indicator records (including absence data) in the Mediterranean and the Black Sea, covering deep water areas inside and outside national jurisdiction, for use by the GFCM Scientific Advisory Committee on Fisheries (SAC) and the Working Group on the Black Sea (WGBS) as well as the wider scientific community. The database contributes to the provision of scientifically robust advice to the GFCM on the distribution of potential VMEs in its area of application and supports the adoption of relevant management measures by decision makers. Analysis tools are integrated within the database (e.g. through RStudio online) and sample analytical scripts (in both R and Python languages) are put at disposal through dedicated repositories to users.  

The database is fed regularly by means of an annual ad hoc data call (January every year) with all available data from scientific surveys, monitoring activities and commercial fisheries regarding observations on habitats/species sensitive to particular fishing activities, i.e., VME indicators, including communities of hydrothermal vents/fields, cold water coral reefs and deep-sea sponge aggregations. 

Criteria to define what constitutes a VME have been produced by the FAO (FAO, 2009) and a VME encounter reporting protocol from fisheries in the GFCM area of application was adopted by the GFCM in 2018 (FAO, 2019). A list of deep-water Mediterranean VME indicators including taxa is also available (FAO, 2019).

objects.abstract: Biomasa de Gambas en las costas de Canarias. Se ha calculado la biomasa a partir de modelos EcoPath-EcoSim, basado en una malla de 2 kilómetros de lado. El área de estudio se ha dividido en cinco partes independientes: Isla de El Hierro, Isla de La Palma, Islas de La Gomera y Tenerife, Isla de Gran Canaria e Islas de Lanzarote y Fuerteventura. Para cada uno de las áreas de estudio se han realizado modelos de distintas especies y/o grupos dependiendo de las carácterísticas de cada uno. En este dataset se compila las especies o grupos de las cinco áreas dentro un sólo grupo trófico para todo el archipiélago. Para poder comparar la abundancia relativa entre las distintas áreas de estudio se ha calculado un índice normalizado para cada una de ellas. Este estudio se ha sido realizado por el IU ECOAQUA-ULPGC y GMR dentro del contexto del proyecto PLASMAR. El dato dado son kilogramos por kilómetro cuadrado. Información  metodológica en http://hdl.handle.net/10553/73660 Proyecto PLASMAR/PLASMAR+   https://www.plasmar.eu/

objects.abstract:
Spillways present along the coast of the municipality of Falconara Marittima.

During rainy events, the overflows pour the urban wastewater into the bathing waters, with activation of the OSG (Management Union Ordinance) which allows for the preventive closure of bathing in the event of activation of the overflow, and subsequently, following deactivation of the overflow and the analyzes of water control by ARPAM with a compliant result, they are reopened for bathing use; this is the first method of health protection with management actions.

The data was produced during the project Watercare project and used in the HATC capitalization project

For more information on the Watercare project and the data, click here

Delimitazione derivata dalle coordinate contenute nel Decreto direttoriale n. 9045689 del 6 agosto 2020 - Decreto di attuazione art. 6, comma 1 del DM 13128 del 31.12.2019 (https://www.politicheagricole.it/flex/cm/pages/ServeBLOB.php/L/IT/IDPagina/15871)

objects.abstract:
Unico file che raccoglie le aree previste per i tre scenari di riferimento (SP, N@W, BD) per le tre aree pilota SoS, NAS e NTS.

Il file incorporerà le revisione a seguito dei workshop MareFuturo

ATTENZIONE:

  1. L'attributo 'Effect'è in corso di aggiornamento. Si chiede ai partner di progetto di controllare e segnalare eventuali effetti non corretti.
  2. In data 24/02/2025 per l'area pilota SoS, scenario N@W, sono state apportate correzioni alle aree di divieto temporaneo di pesca a strascico fino a 6 miglia nautiche dalla costa. Per le aree modificate il valore dell'attributo UseDescIT è stato rinominato da 'Divieto pesca a strascico 0-50/0-6 MN nel periodo estivo' a 'Divieto pesca a strascico 0-6 MN nel periodo estivo'.
